docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
Emmanuel Garza - Software Developer & Applied Mathematician

I'm a Software Developer and Manager working at Divergent in the additive manufacturing sector.

Before joining Divergent, I was a Postdoctoral Scholar at USC under a Computing Innovation Fellowship, working on numerical methods for the solution of electromagnetic problems. In both my postdoc at USC and graduate studies at Caltech, I worked with implementing high-performance methods for solving Maxwell's equations using integral equations, and using those methods together with shape optimization techniques to optimize photonic devices.

docs.title: Professional Experience & Education
docs.text: Linked Divergent Apr 2025 - Present Computational Engineering Manager Apr 2024 - Apr 2025 Lead Software Engineer, Computational Engineering Nov 2021 - Apr 2024 Sr. Software Integration Engineer USC Jul 2020 - Nov 2021 Postdoctoral Scholar               Computing Innovation Fellow 2020          Caltech Sep 2013 - Jan 2020 PhD in Applied and Computational Mathematics Sep 2014 - Dec 2020 Teaching Assistant Tec de Monterrey Aug 2028 - Jun 2013 Bachelor of Science in Engineering Physics

docs.title: Test blog
docs.text:
You enjoy working with Material for MkDocs? Share the love! You can now add a badge to your project's README, showing that your project is built with Material for MkDocs.

Material for MkDocs' logo was just added to [Simple Icons], which is used by [Shields.io] to include logos in badges. We generated a badge for you, which you can add to your project's README:

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Just copy the following snippet and paste it into your project's README.md:

[![Built with Material for MkDocs](https://img.shields.io/badge/Material_for_MkDocs-526CFE?style=for-the-badge&logo=MaterialForMkDocs&logoColor=white)](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/)
test.cpp
#include <iostream>

int main()
{
    std::cout << "Hello World!" << std::endl;
    return 0; // (1)
}
  1. :man_raising_hand: I'm a code annotation! I can contain code, formatted text, images, ... basically anything that can be written in Markdown.

docs.title: Testing a math equation
docs.text:

And my beloved integral equations

\[\begin{equation} \int H(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}') \phi(\mathbf{r}') \text{d} \sigma = - u^\text{inc}(\mathbf{r}) \end{equation}\]
